G.L. c. 208, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: The Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, �������������������������������������������������������� as this concerns an action to modify parenting time and custody arrangements for a minor child of the parties.

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: A modification of the custody and parenting plan is warranted under Massachusetts law because the circumstances of the parties and the needs of Max Collins have substantially and materially changed since the entry of the prior judgment.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the standards for an initial custody determination on appeal, not a post-judgment modification based on a substantial and material change in circumstances. It focuses on the requirement that custody awards be grounded in the child’s best interests and supported by appropriate findings, rather than on the distinct Massachusetts standard for modifying an existing custody and parenting plan. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about modification due to changed circumstances.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: "In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child."

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: Modifications to custody orders must be based on the “best interests of the child” standard as emphasized in *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985).
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly interprets the removal statute’s phrase “upon cause shown” to mean that removal (a modification of where the children will reside under an existing custody order) must be in the child’s best interests and frames the entire removal analysis around the best-interests standard. The court reiterates that “the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern” and then explains how the judge must weigh factors affecting the children, custodial parent, and noncustodial parent. Thus, Yannas is properly cited as emphasizing that post‑divorce custody-related changes must be evaluated under a best‑interests-of-the-child standard.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … [a child] shall not … be removed out of this commonwealth … unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders. The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child … and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.… Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern….”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)..proposition: Defendant’s improved living circumstances qualify as a material change warranting modification.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody determinations based on the child’s best interests, focusing heavily on Rose’s alienating conduct, instability, and wrongful removal of the child, not on any later ‘improved’ living circumstances as a basis for modifying an existing order. There is no analysis of modification standards or of a parent’s improved circumstances constituting a material change; instead, the case concerns an initial custody allocation within a dissolution proceeding. Accordingly, it does not support the proposition that improved living circumstances qualify as a material change warranting modification.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)..relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is]… what is ‘best for the child’… The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’… Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: The age and developmental stage of Max Collins is another critical factor justifying modification.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The opinion in Rolde v. Rolde concerns initial divorce, custody, visitation, and division of marital assets—not a modification proceeding. Nowhere does the court discuss the age or developmental stage of a specific child (such as “Max Collins”) as a factor justifying modification of an existing order. The case instead focuses on best interests, parental conflict, and primary caretaker status, so it does not provide authority for the proposition stated.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Frequent transitions between parents can disrupt a child’s sense of stability and academic performance, which the Court has previously recognized as a basis for modifying visitation schedules.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses relocation and joint physical custody, focusing on the best interests of the child, the quality of schools, developmental disruptions from uprooting, and the impact on the father’s parenting time. It mentions that shuttling children between households can be disruptive only in a quoted secondary source, and does not itself recognize frequent transitions between parents as a basis for modifying visitation schedules or as a distinct ground for changing parenting time. The court neither holds nor clearly affirms the specific proposition about frequent transitions harming stability and academics as a legal basis for modifying visitation.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “Joint physical custody need not necessarily be impeded by relocation outside the Commonwealth. In some cases, distance between the parents may not greatly increase as a result of removal. In addition, there are significant differences in the individual tolerances of the custodians and the children. Wallerstein, supra at 320 (‘Travel plans and arrangements should be tailored to the age, temperament, and wishes of the child’). Cf. Kindregan, supra at 53 (shuttling of children between households ‘by air, bus, or rail . . . extremely disruptive of the child’s social life and development’).”

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.proposition: The parties’ mutual agreement that the current schedule does not meet Max’s needs should factor into this Court’s decision.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.support_reasoning: The concurring opinion in Smith v. McDonald focuses on statutory interpretation under the paternity statute and the limits of a court’s authority to interfere with a fit mother’s relocation when she is the sole legal parent. It does not discuss, much less elevate, any mutual agreement of the parties about a visitation or parenting schedule as a factor that should guide the court’s decision. The analysis is about statutory rights, timing of paternity establishment, and stability, not about giving weight to consensual scheduling agreements between the parties.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate…. Seen in light of the mother’s legitimate New York residence and the provisions of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), the distance separating the parties had relevance only as a factor in devising a reasonable long-distance visitation order….”}
